So, if you've been writing for a few years, attended various classes or workshops, then I presume you possess a stash of half-finished stories and ideas residing in your memory, desk drawer, or hard drive.

Before I delve into my 6-step process for unearthing the magic within your abandoned stories and getting them back on track, allow me to share an anecdote about a writer whose name is already well-known to us all. Yes, another Stephen King writing analogy, I'm afraid. However, this particular story emphasizes how effortlessly we discard ideas with tremendous potential, unrelated to the craftsmanship of writing itself. This tale revolves around "Carrie," King's first published novel. After initially being inspired by the story, he wrote a three-page first draft and promptly discarded it, convinced he disliked it and that it was not worth any more of his time or effort. He believed it would never sell. Yet, his wife, curious about the crumpled pages protruding from his wastebasket, retrieved them, read the story, and loved it. She encouraged him to continue, eager to discover what would happen next. And so, he finished it—and the rest, as they say, is history. He published his debut novel, transcended imminent poverty, and forged a long and successful career.

The takeaway for aspiring authors who remain untapped or unpublished is as follows:
- It is challenging to be objective about our own work.
- It is easy to abandon a story.
- Recognizing the gold amidst the fog of countless rejections is difficult.
- Losing inspiration happens too easily.
- It's particularly challenging to perceive the potential when starting out, the phase during which you're most likely to give up.

May this enduring optimism persist—my romantic view holds that the first draft of any story is a living, breathing entity, existing in the world. Let us embrace the role of treasure hunter ourselves. Who even uses a waste paper basket anymore? Here is my excavation process for seeking out the gems within the mountain of half-finished and forgotten stories amassed over the last seven years of your writing journey.

1. Story hunting:
Put on your gloves and start exploring your spaces. If you're lucky, you're all digital. My handwriting days have left me with a treasure chest of notebooks and pilfered A0 notepads. If this exercise is worth doing, it is worth doing correctly. My creative cellar contains a hard drive, old PC hard drives, notebooks, emails from course tutors, course notes in both physical and digital formats. In this phase, gather everything into one place. Do not worry about reading them just yet. This is a stock-take mode, and it already feels rewarding.

2. Organizing:
I recently realized, to my chagrin, that amidst the relentless pursuit of characters, living a Rimbaud existence, conducting research, and chasing inspiration, the organization of any project plays a crucial role in preventing the loss of our stories. It's time to record the following details: title, draft number, date, source of inspiration, favorite character, and the story's format. To accomplish this, you'll need a spreadsheet. It's an enjoyable process as you remember how much material you've accumulated and recall the adventures experienced along the way.

3. Reading:
The thought of revisiting your old work may fill you with trepidation, but the upsides far outweigh the downsides, as you will soon discover. For every cringe-worthy moment you experience, you can also celebrate how much you have learned and grown as a writer. Most importantly, remember why you embarked on each project initially. Was it due to a person, an injustice, a character, or a response to another piece of literature? Rediscovering that spark of inspiration will undoubtedly compensate for any discomfort you may feel when confronted with your earlier amateur writing. As you peruse your work, make note of the parts you still appreciate. It could be a vivid description of a bluebell woods, an intriguing antagonist, or a brilliant line of dialogue. It is unlikely that you will fail to find something still breathing within each of your old stories.

4. Repositioning:
Now that you are reacquainted with your stories and have recalled their initial inspiration, consider if there is a better way to tell each tale. For instance, a stage play may be better suited as a film script or even a short story. Perhaps that television concept you began writing would flourish as a novel. With your refined storytelling skills, consider if there is a more suitable platform for each story. Remember, the options are limitless: flash fiction, microfiction, novella, novels, films, radio plays, stage plays, short films, web series, or a full series. A former playwriting tutor once imparted this wisdom—though it may seem obvious, I'll reiterate it here. Novels and short stories excel at exploring the conflicts within oneself, while the stage is best suited for delving into interpersonal conflicts. Meanwhile, film is ideal for capturing the conflicts between individuals and the world they inhabit. Pose a few repositioning questions: Is your story in its optimal format? Is your main character dynamic, or is there another character who could take the protagonist's place? As a tutor once remarked during a workshop, the scripts he encountered often featured characters to whom situations were imposed, rather than characters who created their own circumstances.

5. Big Picture:
Now that you have made alterations or confirmed the direction for your story, consider how you will navigate towards your desired destination. What extraordinary events could transform this story into something astonishing? Approach this task just as you would when crafting actions for your characters—think big. Try the "+10 rule." If you lost interest in the idea the first time around, now is the opportunity to take it to an even grander scale. Identify the actions required to make this vision a reality. List everything—whether it means tidying up your workspace, completing existing projects to free up time, adopting a healthier diet, or removing any negative influences from your life. Eliminate all obstacles that stand in the way of you and your story's grander purpose.

6. Action Plan:
The action plan is the simplest step of all. You possess a vision; now add a deadline, set milestones, and outline the small steps needed to complete your task. For instance, find a suitable publishing platform or reach out to a supportive friend via a pleasant email, requesting their feedback on your story—let's think meta! If you are working on a screenplay, the process remains the same. Program your plan into a spreadsheet, utilizing a column or reporting function to track your progress as you move forward.

While there is no shortage of advice on how to make a strong first impression as a writer – from proper formatting to captivating content – we must also consider what comes after that initial encounter.

In many cases, first impressions are either transparent or slick. Readers may not remember their initial impression of a writer, or even if they do, it may not have a lasting impact if it is challenged later on. Therefore, the true measure of success lies in the second impression – the opportunity to forge a durable connection and leave a lasting impression.

Allow me to share a personal experience that exemplifies this concept. There is an author whom I deeply admire. I subscribe to his newsletter, own all his books, and have promoted his work tirelessly. Naturally, my first impression of him was positive, polished, and enticing. This experience highlights the transformative power of the second impression. It signifies a chance to create a lasting bond with followers who have become genuine fans. It made me feel valued and connected, assuaging my concerns about the platform switch. Although the program ultimately faltered, that thoughtful engagement left a lasting imprint, prompting me to explore future offerings from the developer.

This concept applies not only to writers but to all forms of marketing. The first impression is undoubtedly essential, creating a solid foundation and piquing interest. However, it is the second impression that truly determines the success of the marketing endeavor. Title: Reducing Data Transfer Costs in Kafka through Locality Aware Systems

Introduction:
Operating applications in the cloud requires safeguarding against outages by spreading deployments across multiple failure domains. In this article, we explore how making Kafka producers and consumers rack aware and developing locality aware systems can substantially reduce costs. By leveraging data-driven engineering decisions, we can continuously improve fault tolerance and efficiency in cloud environments.

Background:
In a public cloud environment, availability zones (AZ's) serve as failure domains. Traditionally, distributed systems like HDFS have been made rack aware to improve fault tolerance by spreading replicas across multiple racks in a datacenter. However, when running in cloud environments, using AZ's as rack information is a common practice. This enables the spreading of data copies across multiple AZ's, providing fault tolerance in case one fails.

The Challenge:
While replicating data across AZ's provides fault tolerance, it does come with a premium in the form of AZ transfer costs. Pinterest extensively utilizes Kafka as a scalable and fault-tolerant distributed message bus. However, due to its large scale, minimizing the amount of data transferred across AZ's becomes crucial to optimize costs.

Approach:
There are two potential ways to solve the problem. Firstly, we can make our producers and consumers write or read data only for partitions whose leaders share the same AZ, making them more cost-efficient. Alternatively, we could deploy AZ-specific Kafka clusters, but this would require other real-time consumers to make their business logic AZ aware. We chose to implement the first approach as it minimized code and stack changes, ensuring simplicity.

Achieving Producer AZ Awareness:
To make producers AZ aware, we enhanced our logging agent, responsible for reading data from log files and shipping them to Kafka in microbatches. The logging agent now looks up the AZ info for the node it's running on using the EC2 metadata API. We also updated our partitioned to leverage rack information in Kafka's producer metadata, limiting writes to only partitions with leaders in the same AZ as the logging agent. This change was applicable to topics that didn't use key-based partitioning.

Achieving Consumer AZ Awareness:
Similarly, for the S3 transporter, responsible for reading logs from Kafka and persisting them to S3, we implemented AZ awareness. Each S3 transporter worker looks up and publishes its AZ info to ZooKeeper, which helps the S3 transporter master assign Kafka partitions to workers based on their rack (AZ). In cases where the AZ information is unavailable, we default to assignment across all available workers.

Results and Future Work:
The rollout of AZ-aware S3 transporter to production resulted in over 25% savings in AZ transfer costs for logging. Pinterest is gradually rolling out AZ-aware logging agent to further reduce AZ transfer costs. Additionally, efforts are underway to extend this design to standard Kafka producers and consumers, enabling savings for other applications as well.

Acknowledgements:
We would like to thank Eric Lopez, Henry CAI, Hung Zhang, Ping-Min Lin, Valid Baseman, Yi Yin, Indian Qi, You Yang, and Kali Mogul for their valuable contributions in improving logging at Pinterest. END

Overcoming Self-Doubt as a Writer: Strategies for Success

Self-doubt is a common struggle for writers, as the fear of criticism and judgment can hinder our ability to share our work with confidence. In this article, I will discuss three effective strategies that I personally used to overcome my fear of criticism and find success as a writer.

1. Remember, Your Haters Don't Know You:
When faced with criticism or negativity, it is important to remind yourself that those who criticize your work do not truly know you as an individual. Often, these individuals have their own personal agenda or unresolved issues, and your work simply serves as a trigger for them. It is crucial to understand that their reactions say more about them than they do about you. So, rather than engaging in pointless arguments, it is best to close their comments without responding, cleanse your energy if necessary, and move forward.

2. Seek Guidance from Your Future Writing Self:
Without a writing coach, it may be challenging to navigate through self-doubt. However, one effective approach is to imagine your ideal future self as a successful writer. Visualize yourself, six to twelve months from now, with a portfolio of published works and a track record of success. In doing so, you can tap into the wisdom of this version of yourself and ask what steps they would advise you to take. It is highly unlikely that your future self would discourage you from expressing your thoughts for fear of disagreement. Embrace the confidence and guidance of your future self to overcome self-doubt in the present.

3. Write for Your Biggest Fans:
Imagine having a dedicated audience who eagerly awaits your next piece of writing. While you may believe that you lack such fans currently, it is essential to write as if you have them. Writing with enthusiasm and conviction will naturally attract readers who resonate with your work. As I have personally experienced, there have been instances where I discovered unexpected fans through my writing. By focusing on writing for these dedicated supporters, you can establish connections and expand your readership.

In conclusion, self-doubt and fear of criticism are common obstacles for writers. However, it is crucial to remember that unwarranted criticism is often a reflection of the critic's own issues rather than a judgment of your abilities. By connecting with your future writing self, seeking guidance from within, and writing for your hypothetical fan base, you can overcome self-doubt and achieve success in your writing endeavors. The Importance of Understanding the Four Types of Writing

In the world of literature, there are four distinct types of writing, each serving its own purpose. These types include expository, persuasive, narrative, and descriptive writing. Regardless of the genre or subject, every piece of writing falls into one or more of these categories.

Expository writing is a means for authors to inform and educate readers. Its purpose is to explain or teach something. In this article, for instance, I am employing expository writing to elucidate the four types of writing. Textbooks and how-to articles also make use of this style, as they aim to provide clear explanations. Even recipes can be considered a form of expository writing, as they guide the reader on how to complete a culinary creation. Another example of expository writing can be found in newspapers, where writers strive to keep readers informed about daily events.

Persuasive writing, on the other hand, is a way for authors to express their opinions and convince readers to agree with their arguments. This type of writing is commonly found in speeches, scientific studies, medical journals, and even political campaigns. Advertisements, book reviews, editorials, and brochures also utilize persuasive writing techniques. The goal is to persuade the reader to adopt a particular viewpoint. Concrete examples of persuasive writing can be seen in scientific studies and medical journals.

Narrative writing involves the art of storytelling. Authors use this approach to captivate readers by presenting a story, whether fictional or factual, with a main character, a conflict, and a resolution. Fictional stories are considered narrative writing as they follow the journey of a character working through their conflicts in search of resolution. However, non-fiction can also take on a narrative form, as there is still a main character, a conflict, and a plot. Whether real or imagined, narrative writing allows readers to immerse themselves in a captivating tale.

Descriptive writing, a subcategory of expository writing, is characterized by its use of vivid descriptions to paint a picture for the reader. It focuses on creating sensory experiences, involving sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch. Descriptive writing brings characters, settings, and objects to life, enabling readers to visualize the story as they read. It is an essential element in both fiction and non-fiction writing, as it assists in engaging the reader's imagination.

In conclusion, storytelling - whether it be expository, persuasive, narrative, or descriptive - is the art of crafting words that evoke excitement and engagement from the reader. While these four types of writing can be used individually, they can also be combined to convey a powerful and impactful message. Understanding the distinctions between these types of writing allows authors to effectively communicate their ideas and connect with their readers. END

While I have more experience in R, I wanted to provide an introduction to working with startups using a language that I’ve previously used to solve problems. Now that I've completed the series and turned it into a book, I want to start diving into Python as a scripting language for data science. For now, I still prefer Java for production models using data flow, but that preference may change as I become more familiar with the language. I'd like to port some of my previous articles from R to Python to provide an introduction for a broader audience.

Here’s my main motivation for exploring Python startup tooling: Many startups are already using Python for production or portions of their data pipelines. It makes sense to also use Python for performing analysis tasks. PySpark, R, and Java don’t provide a good transition to authoring Spark tasks interactively. You can use Java for Spark, but it's not a good fit for exploratory work, and the transition from Python to PySpark seems to be the most approachable way to learn Spark.

I'm also interested in deep learning, and while there are R bindings for libraries such as Keras, it’s better to code in the native language of these libraries. I previously used R to author custom loss functions, and debugging errors was problematic.

In addition to the deep learning libraries offered for Python, there are a number of other useful tools including Flask and Both. There are notebook environments that can scale, including Google's Colaboratory and AWS Sage Maker.

There are two additional topics that I’d like to cover that I did not provide content for in the initial series: virtualization and Spark. Once you start running large jobs, you need a better environment for scaling up to work with large datasets. I used Google's Data flow in the initial series but want to present tools that are useful for scaling up analysis when working interactively. Spark provides a nice environment for working with large-scale data and moving more easily from exploration to production tasks. To start, I plan on revisiting my previous posts that were R-heavy and providing a port of these posts to Python.

Here are the topics in my original series that need to be translated to Python: many of these sections can be translated directly, but posts such as business intelligence will require using different libraries, such as Both instead of Shiny. I won’t update the sections on Data flow, since those are authored in Java. However, it is possible to write Data flow tasks using Python. Instead of porting Java to Python, I'll explore new tools for production work, such as Spark and Sage Maker.

The goal of this post is to motivate my transition to Python and to provide an introduction to getting up and running with a Jupyter notebook. Given my new focus on virtualization, I also wanted to show how to work with a remote machine on AWS. The remainder of this post discusses how to spin up an EC2 instance on AWS, set up Jupyter notebooks for remote connections, and query data from BigQuery in Python.

Setting up Jupyter:
There are a number of great IDEs available for Python, such as Charm. However, I’m going to be focusing on Jupyter since it’s a notebook environment and many of the tools that are used for scalable data science are based on notebooks, such as Data bricks for Spark, Colaboratory, and Sage Maker. It may be useful to start with an IDE when learning the basics of the language, but it’s good to become familiar with notebook environments given the popularity of this type of environment for large-scale tools. One of the common tasks discussed when getting started with Python is setting up a virtual environment to install Python and any necessary libraries, using tools such as virtual. It’s a good practice to set up a virtual environment when using Python because there may be conflicts between libraries, you may need to run multiple versions of Python, or you may want to create a fresh installation to start over. Docker is another option, but it is much more heavyweight than virtual. For this post, I’ll discuss launching an EC2 instance on AWS to set up a Python 3 environment. This is also much more heavyweight than using virtual, but it provides the ability to scale up the size of the machine if necessary when working with larger datasets. It’s also a good opportunity to become more familiar with AWS and getting started with virtualizing data science tasks. Security is another important consideration when setting up a notebook environment since you don’t want your workspace to be open to the world. The most secure way of connecting to a Jupyter notebook when using AWS is to set up an SSH tunnel with port forwarding, which ensures that clients can only connect to the notebook if they have the required private key. Another option is to open up the notebook to the open web but restrict which machines can connect to the EC2 instance. I’ll present the latter approach in this post since it requires fewer steps, but strongly recommend the former approach for any real task.

Launching an EC2 instance:
This post assumes that you've already created an AWS account. AWS provides a number of free-tier options that you can use to become familiar with the platform. EC2 is a service that you can use to spin up and connect to virtual machines. We'll spin up an EC2 instance and use it to host Jupyter notebooks.

Perform the following steps from the EC2 dashboard to launch a machine:
1. Click "Launch Instance"
2. Select "Amazon Linux AMI 2018.03.0"
3. Select "t2.micro," which is free tier eligible
4. Click "Review and Launch"
5. Click "Launch" and then select a key for connecting via SSH
6. Click "Launch Instances" and then "View Instances"

We'll also need to edit the machine's configuration to allow inbound Jupyter connections on port 8888. By default, an EC2 instance only allows inbound connections on port 22 using a private key for authentication.

Perform the following steps from the EC2 dashboard:
1. Select your EC2 instance
2. Under "Description," select the security (e.g. launch-wizard-1)
3. Click END

Title: Exploring the Inconsistency of the Soul Concept with Everyday Reality

Introduction:

In recent times, the fear of persecution due to differing ideas about the soul has diminished significantly. However, belief in a soul remains prevalent among many individuals. Ironically, this belief stands in stark contrast to the overwhelming evidence that our consciousness and experiences are intricately tied to our brains. This article aims to shed light on the inconsistent nature of the concept of the soul and its incompatibility with our everyday reality.

The Role of Brains in Shaping Consciousness:

Scientific evidence overwhelmingly supports the notion that our brains play a crucial role in shaping our consciousness. Brains gather sensory information and integrate it, enabling us to speak, think, adapt, and navigate through life on this planet. Furthermore, extensive research shows intricate correlations between brain activity and human conscious experiences. This phenomenon extends to other creatures in the animal kingdom, where brains enable survival and overall functionality.

The Analogy of the Brain as a Radio Receiver:

Some proponents of the soul concept argue that the brain serves as a receiver, akin to a radio, which picks up consciousness that exists beyond the physical realm and transmits it into our being. However, this perspective raises questions. If the soul is separate from the physical self, why does the brain seem to play such an obvious role in our conscious experiences? How can we reconcile the apparent involvement of the brain in shaping our consciousness with the concept of an external soul?

The Incongruity of a Dualistic Position:

The idea of a soul acting as a distinct entity, detached from the physical self, leads to further complexities. If the brain has no purpose, why does it consume more energy than the leg muscles of a marathon runner? The evolutionary perspective supports the understanding that brains evolved as an adaptation to interact with the physical world. Therefore, the notion of a brain simultaneously acting as a receiver for extraphysical information raises significant contradictions. It becomes akin to having a bicycle that also functions as a television but with the same parts serving both purposes.

The Purpose of Brains and Organisms:

Consider this: if the soul is the source of consciousness, why would a limited and time-bound entity like the brain or the organism in which it resides need to exist at all? Our survival depends on our ability to perceive and respond to the physical world. If all consciousness originates from the soul, how does it possess the intricate knowledge required to fully comprehend and navigate the mundane world? The soul, if transcendent and eternal, cannot be intimately connected with the physical realm while remaining separate from it.

The Alternative of a Perfect Watcher:

An alternative explanation would be that the soul acts as a perfect watcher, observing our physical actions and manipulating our consciousness accordingly. However, this concept appears more contrived than plausible. If the soul, residing in another dimension, must constantly exert control over our brains and bodies, rendering them mere conduits, it raises questions about the purpose of all the electrochemical activity occurring in the brain. Such a system implies a redundant and inefficient design, contradicting the notion of a perfect and efficient watcher.

The Superfluous Nature of Bodies and the World:

If the soul controls our reality from an external realm, it renders the body and the world it inhabits superfluous. Why would we require a physical body if a remote controller dictated our experiences from beyond our realm? In this scenario, the soul resembles a god-like entity rather than an individual agent. It possesses absolute control over our experience of reality, eliminating the need for the body and the external world altogether. Perhaps the soul is merely engaged in orchestrating a virtual reality game, where we, with our bodies and brains, serve as mere pieces on the board.

The Coordination Issue:

If souls truly exerted control over our realities, why does the collective human experience and the laws governing our world seem consistent? The existence of coordinated experiences suggests a higher form of coordination among souls. However, such a level of coordination demands even more intricate levels of organization and coordination, raising further questions about the plausibility of this perspective. In contrast, the concept of a personal virtual reality, where individual perspectives coexist within a shared base reality, appears more coherent and allows for better understanding.

Conclusion:

While the notion of the brain as a receiver may seem appealing to bridge the gap between the physical world and consciousness, it falls short of providing a satisfactory explanation. Instead, adopting a perspective that integrates the brain's integral role in shaping consciousness within the framework of a shared reality offers a more sensible and consistent understanding. Perhaps all experiences, including transcendent ones, originate from within one universe, with brains actively participating and contributing to our conscious reality. By embracing this perspective, we foster a more comprehensive understanding of consciousness and its relationship with the physical world. END

Self-doubt can often creep in when we least expect it, causing us to question our abilities and fear criticism from potential readers. However, there are strategies we can employ to overcome these doubts and continue publishing our best work. The Four Types of Writing: Each Serving Its Own Purpose

In the world of literature, there are four primary types of writing: expository, persuasive, narrative, and descriptive. These categories encompass different purposes and approaches to writing, each with its own unique characteristics. Understanding these types is crucial for authors aiming to effectively communicate their ideas to their readers.

Expository writing serves the purpose of informing or teaching the reader about a specific subject. It utilizes a language and style that aims to explain complex concepts in a clear and concise manner. This type of writing can be found in articles, textbooks, how-to guides, and even recipes. For instance, this very article aims to provide an expository explanation of the four types of writing. Newspapers also employ expository writing to inform readers about daily events and occurrences.

On the other hand, persuasive writing seeks to convey an author's opinion and ultimately persuade the reader to agree with their argument. This type of writing is commonly found in speeches, scientific studies, medical journals, and political campaigns. Whether encountered in advertisements, book reviews, editorials, or brochures, persuasive writing endeavors to present a well-reasoned case to convince the audience. It is essential to provide solid evidence and logical reasoning to effectively persuade the reader.

Narrative writing, often referred to as storytelling, involves the author recounting a story—whether fact or fiction—to the reader. This type of writing typically features a main character, a conflict that the character must overcome, and a resolution that resolves the conflict. While fiction is the most obvious example of narrative writing, even non-fiction works can be considered narrative as they still involve a protagonist, conflict, and plot. The goal of narrative writing is to engage the reader and take them on a journey through the story, captivating their imagination and emotions.

Descriptive writing, a variant of expository writing, employs detailed visual descriptions to immerse the reader in a story. It vividly captures scenery, emotions, and actions in a way that resonates with the reader and allows them to visualize the narrative in their mind. Descriptive writing can be used in conjunction with the other types of writing, as it brings life to characters, settings, and events. It requires skillful attention to detail in order to effectively engage the reader's senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch.

In conclusion, whether expository, persuasive, narrative, or descriptive, storytelling lies at the heart of all types of writing. These different forms can be combined or employed individually to convey a specific message or evoke excitement and interest in the reader. Understanding and utilizing these types of writing will enable authors to effectively communicate their ideas and engage their audience. END

We have been receiving numerous inquiries regarding how to customize a single QuickSight dashboard to display user-specific data. This can be achieved by utilizing AWS QuickSight's row-level security feature to filter the dashboard data based on the login username. To further illustrate this use case, let's consider a scenario within a sales department of a company. Every day, a team of sales agents contacts a list of potential customers. Now, there is a need for a single dashboard accessed by all agents that displays only the prospects assigned to each individual agent. It is important to note that this requirement is distinct from the standard filter and control functionalities available on QuickSight dashboards.

To address this use case, we will create data set rules for row-level security. Firstly, a file or query containing the dataset rules, also known as permissions, must be created. The order of the fields in the file or query is irrelevant, but all fields are case-sensitive and must exactly match the field names and values. It is essential to include at least one field that identifies either users or groups. Both users and groups can be included, but only one is required and used at a time. When specifying groups, it is important to use either Amazon QuickSight groups or Microsoft AD groups.

Here is an example of a table with usernames in SQL format for specifying users:

SELECT user as username, agent as agent_assigned
FROM permissions_table

Alternatively, a CSV file can be used with the "username" and "agent_assigned" columns:

username, agent_assigned
Nick, Nick Howe
Diva, Diva Medal
Manager, Nick Howe, Diva Medal

The "agent_assigned" column represents a column in the dataset, while "username" corresponds to the QuickSight login name. This mapping links the username with the agent_assigned column. For instance, if Diva has logged in, only records with the condition agent_assigned = "Diva Medal" will be retrieved. The same applies to Nick. However, in the case of the manager, who should have superuser access, all agent names (values in the agent_assigned column) are included.

For Athena, RDS, Redshift, or S3 CSV file-based datasets, ensure that the output format and structure of those sources match the aforementioned formats.

Next, create a QuickSight dataset with the aforementioned data set rules by going to "Manage data," selecting "New data set," choosing the appropriate data source, and creating it accordingly. If using a CSV file, upload it and provide a meaningful name, such as "permissions-prospects-list," for easy identification. After completing these steps, refresh the page as the dataset may not immediately appear in the data sources list during the application to the dataset.

To implement row-level security, select "Permissions" and choose the permissions' dataset created earlier. Then, select "Apply dataset." Once applied, the dataset will display a new lock symbol, indicating that it is restricted and that the data is now filtered and secured based on the username.

3 Ways Over-Editing is Negatively Impacting Your Writing and How to Overcome it

In today's fast-paced digital age, it's easy to become overwhelmed with the desire for our writing to be perfect before sharing it with the world. However, over-editing can do more harm than good, stifling our creativity and preventing us from effectively communicating our message. Let's explore three ways over-editing is killing your writing and discover how you can break free from this destructive cycle.

1. Setting Realistic Time Limits
One of the main culprits of over-editing is an unlimited amount of time spent perfecting our work. By continuously making revisions, we delay the publishing process and hinder our productivity. Just like you have deadlines for important tasks in your life, it's crucial to set time limits for your writing as well. Allocate specific time slots for drafting, editing, and seeking feedback. With practice, you'll find that the process becomes more efficient, enabling you to produce fresh content regularly.

2. Avoid Editing as You Write
The temptation to edit as you write can drain your time and energy. Instead, focus on capturing your thoughts and ideas in an uninterrupted draft. Consider your writing as a canvas waiting to come to life. By allowing yourself to freely express your thoughts without the constant interruption of editing, you will preserve the rawness and authenticity of your words. Once you've completed your draft, set aside dedicated time to work on spelling, grammar, filling in information gaps, and removing anything that doesn't add value to your message. Remember, your goal should be to enhance your writing, not to polish it to the point of losing its essence.

3. Embrace Your Unique Perspective
While it's essential to learn from experienced writers, it's equally important to have the confidence to share your own perspective. Don't limit yourself to repeating what has already been said. Challenge conventional wisdom and give voice to your thoughts, experiences, and opinions. What sets you apart from others is your unique voice and your ability to provide fresh insights. Remember that you are not expected to please everyone or have all the answers. By sharing your original ideas, you will stand out among a sea of imitators and make a lasting impact on your readers.

Overcoming the Fear of Publishing
Fear of negative feedback or rejection often holds writers back. It's natural to feel apprehensive about sharing your work with the world, but it's crucial to push through this fear. Remind yourself that not everyone will agree with or appreciate your writing, and that's perfectly okay. Focus on delivering your absolute best within the constraints of your time and resources. The key to growth and success as a writer lies in taking calculated risks and continually improving. Embrace the messiness of life, knowing that it's through embracing risk that true growth and progress are achieved.

Concluding Thoughts
While editing is an essential part of the writing process, it's important to approach it with balance and purpose. Don't obsess over achieving perfection; instead, prioritize simplicity, possibility, and usability in your writing. When your work is understandable, encouraging, and motivating, it will resonate with your readers and make a meaningful impact. Embrace the journey of writing and editing, and trust that your words have the power to make a difference in the world. Now, go forth and create purposefully, leaving behind the constraints of over-editing. END

It serves as a poignant reminder of the dire consequences that can arise if patriarchal ideologies are allowed to flourish.

Written during World War II, Anne Frank's diary not only served as an outlet for her emotions while hiding from the Nazis but also documented her experiences and compiled her memories for posterity. - Discussions of uncomfortable truths

How to Scale Python on Every Major Cloud Provider: Best Practices for Cloud Computing

In the words of Eric Jonas, the creator of Wren, "the cloud is too damn hard!" Scaling Python applications in the cloud can be a challenging task, especially without the help of an infrastructure team. Choices like Kubernetes may not be straightforward. However, with the use of cloud providers such as AWS, GCP, and Azure, you can scale your Python applications efficiently. In this article, we will explore how to use Ray, a powerful Python framework, to launch clusters and scale Python applications on any of these cloud providers with just a few commands.

To get started, there are three main steps:

Step 1: Develop your Python application locally or in the cloud of your choice.
Step 2: Launch a cluster on your preferred cloud provider.
Step 3: Run your application on the cluster.

To begin, you will need to install some Python dependencies, namely Ray, Boto3, Azure CLI, Azure Core, and Google API Python client. Install these dependencies using pip with the following command:

pip install -u ray boto3 azure-cli azure-core google-api-python-client

Next, you need to configure the credentials for your chosen cloud provider. If you already have command line access to your cloud provider, you can skip this step. Otherwise, follow the specific instructions for each provider:

- For AWS, configure your credentials in the ~/.AWS/credentials file as described in the Both documentation.
- For Azure, log in using "AZ login," then configure your credentials with "AZ account set -s <subscription_id>."
- For GCP, set the "google_application_credentials" environment variable as described in the documentation.

The Ray cluster launcher uses a configuration file that allows you to specify various parameters such as setup commands, instance types, files to sync, autoscaling strategies, and more. Here is a minimal example of a cluster configuration file:

[cluster_config]
# Specify details of your cluster here

For a more complete example, please refer to the documentation and fetch the appropriate configuration file for your cloud provider.

Once you have the configuration file, make a few minor modifications, such as replacing the key files and setting the project ID for GCP.

Now, let's walk through the three steps to scale your Python application:

Step 1: Create a Python application
Develop a simple Python script that you want to scale up. This script can be run on your laptop or in the cloud and uses Ray for parallel computation. You can find an example script in the provided link. Run the script using the following command:

python script.py

Step 2: Start the cluster
To start the cluster, execute the following command:

# For AWS
ray up -y aws-config.yaml

# For Azure
ray up -y azure-config.yaml

# For GCP
ray up -y gcp-config.yaml

Step 3: Run the script on the cluster
Finally, you can run the script on the cluster using the command:

# For AWS
ray submit aws-config.yaml script.py

# For Azure
ray submit azure-config.yaml script.py

# For GCP
ray submit gcp-config.yaml script.py

Once run, you will see the output indicating the resources and tasks executed on the cluster. If there is a delay in the cluster startup, you may need to wait for all nodes to become active.

To connect to the cluster, use the following commands:

# For AWS
ray attach aws-config.yaml

# For Azure
ray attach azure-config.yaml

# For GCP
ray attach gcp-config.yaml

Remember to shut down the cluster when you're done:

# For AWS
ray down -y aws-config.yaml

# For Azure
ray down -y azure-config.yaml

# For GCP
ray down -y gcp-config.yaml

One advantage of using Ray is its extensibility. If you want to add support for a new cloud provider, you can extend the NodeProvider class, which typically requires 200-300 lines of code. Take a look at the AWS implementation for reference.

In conclusion, scaling Python applications on major cloud providers like AWS, GCP, and Azure can be simplified using Ray. By following the three steps outlined in this article, you can easily launch clusters and scale your Python applications to meet your needs. END

Streaming Data from the Universe with Apache Kafka: How Astronomers Deploy Real-Time Pipelines to Distribute Data from the Millions of Objects Discovered Each Night by Modern Telescopes 

In the field of astronomy, data collection has evolved from a solitary astronomer pointing a telescope at a single object in a static sky to a data-intensive science with real-time needs. Modern telescopes, through large-scale astronomical telescope surveys, detect millions of changing objects in the sky each night and require a seamless stream of data to scientists for time-sensitive follow-up observations. Apache Kafka presents an ideal solution for this data pipeline.

Observational astronomers study various types of objects, ranging from asteroids in our own solar system to galaxies that are billions of light years away. While individual astronomical objects typically change over millions of years, a telescope can detect millions of objects that appear to be changing in a single night. These objects, known as transients, encompass phenomena such as variable stars, gamma-ray bursts, supernovae, and moving objects in the solar system like asteroids. To detect and study these transient objects, astronomers collaborate on "sky survey" telescopes that collect data by sweeping across the night sky instead of focusing on pre-selected targets. One early pioneer of this survey technique is the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), which has collected a massive amount of image data from nearly 1 billion objects. By comparing the latest survey images to previous reference images, astronomers can identify objects that have changed in brightness or position. To fully characterize transient objects, astronomers need to gather data from other telescopes at different wavelengths in near real time. This requirement is especially critical for time-sensitive events like supernova "shock breakouts" that last only minutes.

Recently, the Ricky Transient Facility (ZTF) has come online with the aim of quickly detecting transient objects. ZTF images the entire northern sky every three nights and detects approximately 1,000 objects in each image taken every 45 seconds, resulting in approximately 1 million changing objects per night. The data processing pipeline characterizes these objects, extracting key parameters such as brightness, color, elasticity, and coordinate location, and broadcasts this information in alert packets. 

Before transitioning to Apache Kafka, the detection rate of transient objects was relatively low, and existing alert distribution mechanisms sufficed. However, with ZTF's detection rate increasing significantly, a fully automated and scalable streaming alert distribution system became necessary. Furthermore, ZTF serves as a precursor survey for the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), which is expected to detect approximately 10 million transient objects each night, thereby generating a nightly data stream of 1-2 TB of messages. Thus, the underlying technology of the ZTF system should be a reliable prototype that can accommodate LSST's needs.

Several factors were considered while designing the alert distribution system for ZTF. Firstly, the system needed to reliably distribute each alert message and allow downstream listeners to rewind or catch up in real time without losing data in the event of a dropped connection or slow consumer. The Virtual Observatory Event Transport Protocol, the existing standard alert distribution system, acts as a broadcast system that transmits alerts if a user is connected. Kafka's consumer offset management and the ability for consumers to rewind to the beginning of a topic became attractive features for ZTF. Since the alerts are scientific quality data, preserving the integrity of the data so that it can be correctly interpreted by end-user scientists is crucial. The predominant existing astronomical alert format, XML, falls short in cases where scientists need to analyze millions of alerts per night. Therefore, ZTF decided to leverage Afro, an open-source, JSON-based binary format, for serializing data in the alert messages. Afro provides compactness, simplicity, schema evolution, and Python libraries for data manipulation.

User-friendliness was another essential consideration for the end-user, primarily astronomers. To support their preferences, the ZTF alert distribution system was built in Python using Confluent's Python client for Apache Kafka. 

The ZTF telescope, situated at the Palomar Observatory in California, captures images of the sky at a rate of approximately one image every 45 seconds. The data then undergoes processing at Caltech's Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPA). The images are cleaned to remove instrumental and atmospheric effects and differenced to identify transient candidates. The resulting detections are serialized into Afro binary format. The Afro alert data schemas for ZTF are defined in JSON documents and published to GitHub for deserializing data upon receipt. As part of the alert data distribution, a small cutout image or "postage stamp" of the transient candidate is included. With Afro, data fields can be serialized as type bytes, allowing for the inclusion of binary format data such as image cutouts.

Serialized alerts are produced to a Kafka broker, with each night's data written to its own topic. Data older than two weeks is expired from the Kafka system. The IPA Kafka broker is accessible to two external consumers: a downstream Kafka system at the University of Washington (UW) and another Kafka system in a commercial cloud. Mirror maker is used to mirror available alert stream topics between these systems. The UW system runs a cluster of three Kafka brokers (deployed in separate Docker containers) that feed a permanent data archive of Afro files, accommodating connections from various external collaborations of scientists focused on different subfields of astronomy. The topics are partitioned into 16 partitions to enable parallel reading and downstream filtering and processing at a group level of up to 16.

Downstream filtering algorithms classify and separate different types of objects. End-user scientists can subscribe to topics of interest, and collaborations of scientists, termed event brokers, can also subscribe and redistribute alerts enriched with additional external data. The cloud-based Kafka system is public-facing for other astronomy researchers. Scientists can write scientific filters to automatically apply algorithms for detecting and tagging different types of objects, such as supernovae, variable stars, or near-Earth objects. These filters can be written in Python and deployed separately in different Docker containers.

The ZTF pipeline generates between 600,000 and 1.2 million alerts per night, with stress tests showing potential for handling up to 2 million alerts without technical issues. Each alert packet is approximately 60 KB in size, primarily due to the inclusion of cutout images, resulting in a total volume of up to 70 GB of data processed nightly. Serialized alert data is made available to end users roughly 20 minutes after an image is taken, with the image differencing pipeline accounting for the majority of the processing time. The transfer time from the main Kafka distribution hub to external consumers is approximately four seconds.

Apache Kafka has proven to be an invaluable tool for addressing the challenges in the distribution and analysis of astronomical data in real time. Its ease of use and compatibility with existing scientific workflows have made it a favorite among astronomers. As we continue to explore the potential of Apache Kafka, we aim to facilitate real-time data science pipelines for future projects at High Alpha Studio.

For more information, you can download the Confluent Platform, the leading distribution of Apache Kafka. Maria Patterson, an expert in optimizing scientific data analysis pipelines with a Ph.D. in astronomy, has played an integral role in various astronomical projects, including cloud-based pipelines for satellite imagery processing and the development of a science "data commons" for NOAA's big data project. Maria's current focus is on enabling the distribution of real-time object detection alert streams from large-scale telescopes. She is recognized for her contributions to the Ricky Transient Facility and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. Maria is currently a data scientist at High Alpha, where she supports new cloud companies in leveraging data science.
